docs.lead_paragraph: THE nerve center of a conventional robot is a microprocessor of silicon and metal. But for a robot under development at Georgia Tech, commands are relayed by 2,000 or so cells from a rat's brain. A group led by a university researcher has created a part mechanical, part biological robot that operates on the basis of the neural activity of rat brain cells grown in a dish. The neural signals are analyzed by a computer that looks for patterns emitted by the brain cells and then translates those patterns into robotic movement. If the neurons fire a certain way, for example, the robot's right wheel rotates once.
docs.abstract: Georgia Tech Prof Steve M Potter has developed Hybrot, short for hybrid robot, part mechanical and part biological robot that operates on basis of neural activity of rat brain cells grown in lab dish; hopes close observation of how brain cells behave as they are exposed to world of sensation will help researchers understand more about learning process; drawing (M)

headline.main: Wired to the Brain of a Rat, a Robot Takes On the World

docs.lead_paragraph: An academic who had no rhythm spent a sabbatical finding a way to learn to play the guitar.
docs.abstract: Cognitive psychologist Gary Marcus spent year-long sabbatical learning to play the guitar, experience he has chronicled in book Guitar Zero: The New Musician and the Science of Learning; book explores connection between neuroscience and music, as well as the limits of his own musical abilities.

docs.lead_paragraph: VISIONS of Furby -- a talking, winking, learning, cuddly toy -- danced in children's heads two Christmases ago. Engineers, however, undressed Furby with their eyes, saw the sophisticated robotics that lay underneath, and yearned to extend Furby beyond its hard-wired programming. Last month, an engineer got under Furby's skin and won a long-standing Hack Furby contest by building a set of replacement circuit boards to allow a programmer access to the toy's infrared port, motors, position sensors, microphone and speaker.
docs.abstract: Peter Gibbons wins $250 by building set of replacement circuit boards for Furby that allow a programmer access to toy's infrared port, motors, position sensors, microphone and speaker; Peter van der Linden, software engineer, created contest (M)

byline.original: By ANDREA ELLIOTT; John Schwartz contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Jef Raskin, a computer technology pioneer who started the team that created the Macintosh computer, died Saturday at his home in Pacifica, Calif., at age 61. The cause was pancreatic cancer, said his wife, Linda Blum. Mr. Raskin, who named the Macintosh after his favorite apple but altered the spelling for copyright reasons, played a significant role in transforming computers into friendlier machines, helping to catapult them into the commercial sphere. As the 31st employee at Apple Computer, Mr. Raskin advocated forcefully for the company to develop a computer that was easy for people to use, and he headed the Macintosh project starting in 1979.
docs.abstract: Jef Raskin, computer technology pioneer who started team that created Macintosh computer, dies at age 61; photo; Raskin named Macintosh after his favorite apple; he left company after relationship with Steve Jobs soured (M)
